name: foreign
content:
foreign

adjective
 OPAL S
 
/ˈfɒrən/
 
/ˈfɔːrən/
jump to other results
  1. ​
     
     in or from a country that is not your own
    • What foreign languages do you speak?
    • It can be a challenge at first living in a foreign country.
    • I went to the bank to get some foreign currency.
    • a foreign-owned company
    • foreign holidays
    • He spoke with a foreign accent.
    • You could tell she was foreign by the way she dressed.
    Extra Examples
    • The name sounded foreign.
    • She had no money and was alone in a foreign country.
    • The cinema often shows foreign films.
    • The collection of plants includes many native and foreign species.
    • There were very few foreign cars on the roads in those days.
    • Tourism is the country's biggest foreign currency earner.
    Topics Holidaysa2
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryverbs
    • be
    • look
    • sound
    • …
    adverb
    • slightly
    • distinctly
    See full entry
  2. ​
     
     [only before noun] dealing with or involving other countries
    • This is a huge departure for the country's foreign policy.
    • The country relies heavily on foreign aid.
    • The area is trying to attract foreign investment.
    • Iran's foreign ministry
    • the Japanese foreign minister
    • a foreign correspondent (= one who reports on foreign countries in newspapers or on television)
    opposite domestic, home
    Extra Examples
    • The new president had no experience of foreign affairs.
    • There have been changes in both domestic and foreign policy.
    Topics Politicsa2
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryverbs
    • be
    • look
    • sound
    • …
    adverb
    • slightly
    • distinctly
    See full entry
  3. ​foreign to somebody/something (formal) not typical of somebody/something; not known to somebody/something and therefore seeming strange
    • Dishonesty is foreign to his nature.
    • This kind of attitude is completely foreign to her.
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryverbs
    • be
    • feel
    • seem
    • …
    adverb
    • very
    • completely
    • entirely
    • …
    See full entry
  4. ​foreign object/body (formal) an object that has entered something by accident and should not be there
    • Tears help to protect the eye from potentially harmful foreign bodies.
    More Like This Silent lettersSilent letters

name: foreign exchange
content:
foreign exchange

noun
 
/ˌfɒrən ɪksˈtʃeɪndʒ/
 
/ˌfɔːrən ɪksˈtʃeɪndʒ/
jump to other results
  1. ​[uncountable, countable] the system of exchanging the money of one country for that of another country; the place where money is exchanged
    • The euro fell on the foreign exchanges yesterday.
  2. ​[uncountable] money that is obtained using this system
    • our largest source of foreign exchange
See foreign exchange in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: foreign exchange

name: foreign-returned
content:
foreign-returned

adjective
 
/ˌfɒrən rɪˈtɜːnd/
 
/ˌfɔːrən rɪˈtɜːrnd/
(Indian English, informal)
jump to other results
  1. ​(of a person) educated or trained in a foreign country, and having returned to India
Check pronunciation: foreign-returned

name: Foreign Service
content:
Foreign Service

noun
 
/ˈfɒrən sɜːvɪs/
 
/ˈfɔːrən sɜːrvɪs/
 (North American English)
(also the Diplomatic Service especially in British English)
jump to other results
  1. ​the government department concerned with representing a country in foreign countriesTopics Politicsc2
See Foreign Service in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: Foreign Service

name: the Foreign Office
content:
the Foreign Office

noun
 
/ðə ˈfɒrən ɒfɪs/
 
/ðə ˈfɔːrən ɑːfɪs/
[singular + singular or plural verb]
(abbreviation FO)
jump to other results
  1. ​the British government department that deals with relations with other countries, now officially called ‘the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office’
Check pronunciation: the Foreign Office
matches: the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office noun
relatives: the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office noun

name: the Foreign Secretary
content:
the Foreign Secretary

noun
 
/ðə ˌfɒrən ˈsekrətri/
 
/ðə ˌfɔːrən ˈsekrəteri/
jump to other results
  1. ​the British government minister in charge of the department that deals with relations with other countries (= the Foreign and Commonwealth Office)
    CultureThe full title is Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs. It is one of the most important jobs in the government. The Foreign Secretary represents Britain at many international meetings, and discusses foreign policy with the Prime Minister.
    Topics Politicsc2
Check pronunciation: the Foreign Secretary

name: foreign direct investment
content:
foreign direct investment

noun
 
/ˌfɒrən dəˌrekt ɪnˈvestmənt/,
 
/ˌfɒrən daɪˌrekt ɪnˈvestmənt/
 
/ˌfɔːrən dəˌrekt ɪnˈvestmənt/,
 
/ˌfɔːrən daɪˌrekt ɪnˈvestmənt/
(also direct investment)
(abbreviation FDI)
[uncountable, countable]
jump to other results
  1. ​the act of a person or organization from one country investing in a business in another country in order to get control of it
    • The United States and Japan will work toward promoting more foreign direct investment in each other's markets.
    • The analysts said other countries could also increase their direct investments in Cuba.
    Topics Moneyc2
Check pronunciation: foreign direct investment
nearBys: the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office noun

name: the Foreign Relations Committee
content:
the Foreign Relations Committee

 
/ðə ˌfɒrən rɪˈleɪʃnz kəmɪti/
 
/ðə ˌfɔːrən rɪˈleɪʃnz kəmɪti/
(also Senate Committee on Foreign Relations)
jump to other results
  1. ​a committee of the US Senate that studies the American government's policy towards other countries, and offers advice and criticism
Check pronunciation: the Foreign Relations Committee

name: the Veterans of Foreign Wars
content:
the Veterans of Foreign Wars

 
/ðə ˌvetərənz əv ˌfɒrən ˈwɔːz/
 
/ðə ˌvetərənz əv ˌfɔːrən ˈwɔːrz/
(abbreviation VFW)
jump to other results
  1. ​a large organization for former members of the US armed forces who fought in wars abroad. It helps those in need, has campaigns to influence the government on military matters, and does community service. It was established in 1899. compare American Legion
Check pronunciation: the Veterans of Foreign Wars
